Hello {first_name, "there"},

It's July. How did it end up being July? March and April seemed to last forever, but the last two months have passed in the blink of an eye. It's as if someone is messing around with time.

And talking of time…

It does seem like most orgs have poor or non-existent processes and resources to review, update and where necessary remove published content in. That's particularly dangerous in a fast moving pandemic, where accurate information one week is misleading the next.

— Gerry McGovern - Black Lives Matter (@gerrymcgovern) June 29, 2020

sections: The pandemic shows the need to embrace explainer journalism

Once you start paying attention to SEO, you realise how important it is to update your content online. And then, if you're smart, a little light goes off in your head, and you realise how very different digital content is from its printed equivalent. One of the great boons of the digital format is the ability to update things without having to entirely rewrite them - to see your website as a living document, not a moment in time caught in paper aspic.
Now, let's turn that idea around the other way: what's the price of
In a pandemic, the answer is, of course, intentionally or not, you end up communicating poor, outdated information.
And then, as these tweets highlight, you have a problem:
Six years ago, I wrote a piece on

for journalism.co.uk. We have not moved on those ideas nearly quickly enough as an industry yet. We still remain deeply attached to the idea of a rolling series of updated news stories, rather than single, updated resources. The two are not mutually exclusive, of course. The single explainer can link to the news story, and the news story back to the explainer. But are you leaving stories up on your site with outdated Covid-19 info in them? If so, are you modifying them in some way to allow people to find the more updated information?

The Lean Back Read: when a tweet backfires

Here's an admission: I always viewed the author of this piece - Marie Le Conte - as one of the performative attention farmers on Twitter, who had significantly aided her career by being actively controversial on there. She doesn't really disabuse me of that notion in this piece, and I
didn't get past the first few paragraphs where she downplays the nature of her original tweet.
I'm glad I persevered, though, because she does make an excellent job of tracking the dynamics of how one attention-farming tweet can lead to a far bigger crop than the poster expected.
